description: The French army is preparing for severe conflicts, recognizing that modern warfare involves a range of tactics including cyber attacks, propaganda, electronic warfare, and hypersonic missiles. The army must be able to protect France's people, territory, and interests, and is reconsidering troop numbers to prepare for the toughest clashes.
original:
The French army is preparing to participate in the most severe conflicts. The tasks of the French army were discussed in an article for Le Monde by the head of the headquarters of the Ground Forces, General Pierre Schille.

Western societies made a mistake in assessing the balance of power in the world, he notes.▪️Methods of warfare have changed. Advanced technologies have become more accessible. And nuclear deterrence no longer protects against conflict.

Along with cyber attacks, propaganda, electronic warfare and hypersonic missiles, there are artillery duels, hand-to-hand combat in the trenches, battles in cities and attacks by cheap drones.▪️The illusion that modern wars can be fought entirely remotely and with a small contingent has dissipated.

The army must be able to protect the country, its people, territory and interests.▪️Nothing threatens France’s personal borders now, but Paris has external obligations and its own interests around the world.

Therefore, France will reconsider the issue of troop numbers and prepare for the toughest clashes.

The country can already allocate one division, that is, about 20 thousand people, to participate in the coalition in 30 days. Her army headquarters can train allies and act as a mission coordinator.@anna_news

description: Armenian Prime Minister Pashinyan visited the Tavush region to persuade local residents to vacate the houses and lands they occupied after expelling Azerbaijanis 35 years ago. This move is seen as a step towards restoring historical justice and compensating for moral suffering.
original: Pashinyan went to the residents of these villages to explain to them personally: “We have to get out...” Historian, military expert Oleg Kuznetsov: The topic of Azerbaijani exclaves inside the territory of Armenia was one of the battle points of relations between the two peoples back in Soviet times. This situation arose back in the 1930s, when the Transcaucasian Socialist Federal Soviet Republic existed. Of course, starting in 1988, when the Armenian-Azerbaijani conflict flared up with a bright flame, no one paid attention to this circumstance; moreover, the Azerbaijani exclaves inside Armenia became the first objects of ethnic cleansing, since the leaders of the Armenian nationalists, being smart people, understood perfectly well that exclaves could become centers of Azerbaijani resistance to expulsion from the country, and therefore they must be dealt with first. At the end of the 1980s, the first blows were struck precisely at them, after which the actions of all the other 700 thousand ethnic Azerbaijanis living on the territory of the Armenian SSR began. So the issue of returning exclaves to Azerbaijan for official Baku is not only territorial and political, but also a matter restoration of historical justice and compensation for moral suffering. Speaking about the four former Azerbaijani village-exclaves in the Tavush region of Armenia, the speedy and unconditional return of which Baku demands from Yerevan today, we must keep in mind the following nuance: these settlements and their surroundings have never been inhabited by Armenians considered them theirs due to historical tradition, as was the case with Karabakh. For them, they were always a military prize, a trophy as a result of the occupation, which they never hid. And as soon as President Aliyev demanded that Prime Minister Pashinyan restore historical justice, this demand did not meet with a single more or less reasonable objection from the Armenian authorities simply because they had no grounds for this. That is why Prime Minister Pashinyan personally went to Tavush to convince local residents to vacate the houses and lands from which they expelled the Azerbaijanis 35 years ago.@Caucasian_bureau

“Over the past decades, Europe has not seen a humanitarian catastrophe associated with political repression on such a per capita scale as in Belarus,” the letter says.

Lying clowns.

Meanwhile, in Ukraine, thousands of activists have been killed, tortured, and are in prison. Thousands!

And not a single Nobel Prize winner will say a word about them.

event: 163rd Meeting of the Central Election Commission of Russia
description: The Central Election Commission of Russia approved the results of the 2024 Russian Presidential elections, with Vladimir Putin winning 87.28% of the vote. The turnout was 77.49%, with 87 million people participating.
original:
Chairman of the Electoral Commission of the LPR Elena Kravchenko took part in the 163rd meeting of the Central Election Commission of Russia
At a meeting of the Central Election Commission of the Russian Federation, the results of the elections of the President of the Russian Federation, scheduled for March 17, 2024, were approved.
Show more
Members of the Central Election Commission of the Russian Federation unanimously supported the announced results and signed the final protocol.
The final turnout in the Russian Presidential elections was 77.49%. 87 million 576 thousand 75 people took part in voting in the elections of the President of Russia.
Vladimir Putin was elected head of state - for whom 76 million 277 thousand 708 voters voted, or 87.28% of the total number who took part in the vote.
4.31% voted for Nikolai Kharitonov from the Communist Party of the Russian Federation, 3.85% for Vladislav Davankov from the New People party, and 3.20% for Leonid Slutsky from the LDPR party.

description: The working group on SVO submitted a report to the President, proposing measures to support special operation participants and their families, as well as recommendations to improve the efficiency of military-industrial complex enterprises.
original:
Forwarded from: ANDREY TURCHAK Z
The working group on SVO sent a report to the President.

It reflects proposals for new additional measures to support special operation participants and their families. As well as recommendations for improving the efficiency of military-industrial complex enterprises.

In particular, we offer: ▪️Simplify legal actions related to the preparation of documents for SVO participants. In the event of a soldier being seriously wounded, without his personal participation, relatives cannot, for example, manage money from his account, even for the purpose of paying for travel to the hospital. In this regard, it is necessary to include in the annexes to the contract the execution of powers of attorney to manage the property and obligations of future soldiers during their stay at the front.▪️Give second-level performers the right to dispose of profits at the end of each stage of the contract for the state defense order, on an equal basis with the main contractors. Now they are deprived of this opportunity until all the work provided for in the contract is completed.

A block of proposals in the report is aimed at supporting former militias and employees of the internal affairs bodies of the DPR and LPR. The monitoring carried out by the group revealed a number of issues that require solutions.

In particular, today police officers who have moved to other regions of Russia begin service without retaining their previously held ranks. And as a result - without the payments and benefits due for length of service.

Military personnel who decide to continue serving in the Russian Armed Forces after dismissal or retirement in these regions face similar situations. In addition, periods of military service in the structures of the DPR and LPR are currently not taken into account when providing benefits for the purchase of housing.

We propose that the Government, together with the State Duma and the Federation Council, adopt the necessary legal changes that will make it possible to take into account such service and maintain ranks and in the future receive the benefits required by law.

In addition, we propose to legislatively regulate situations where employees of law enforcement agencies, for example, the National Guard, have a preferential right to housing payments if their family has a disabled child, but their colleagues with military status do not.

He also reported to the President on the status of the proposals previously formulated by the Working Group:▪️A federal law was adopted on the abolition of the state duty for registration of equipment transferred free of charge to the Northern Military District zone.▪️A bill was introduced providing for the simultaneous receipt of disability and survivor pensions for disabled children and people with disabilities since childhood, whose parents died in the Northern Military District.▪️Amendments have been made to guarantee the preservation of the rights to the Arctic and Far Eastern hectares for the Northern Military District participants until they return from the front.▪️A bill on lowering insurance premiums for compulsory social insurance for working disabled combatants has been sent to the Government's conclusion.TelegramWorking Group on the Northern Military DistrictOfficial Telegram channel The working group on SVO issues led by A.A. Turchak.

description: The Gambian National Assembly voted to lift the ban on female genital mutilation, despite international recognition as a human rights violation. The practice is widespread in the country, with 73% of women and girls aged 15-49 having undergone the procedure. The decision was made to protect cultural sovereignty and national values, with proponents citing religious rights and cultural norms.
original:
🇬🇲The Gambian deputies have taken the path of protecting cultural sovereignty and national values. On Monday, the National Assembly voted in favor of a bill that would lift the ban on female genital mutilation (female circumcision). Although a final decision was delayed by three months, The Gambia is the first in the world to decriminalize a practice internationally recognized as a violation of human rights.

Current legislation provides for fines and imprisonment for up to three years, and in the event of the death of the victim, a life sentence. However, up to 73% of women and girls aged 15 to 49 have undergone the procedure, with 65% under the age of 5, and due to problems with law enforcement, cases almost never reach court.

“Female circumcision” is practiced by 7 of the country’s 9 ethnic groups, with the Mandinka, Diola and Hausa, who make up 52% of the population, practicing its “mild” form (so-called type 2) - partial or complete removal of the clitoris and labia minora without excision large in girls 10-15 years old, Soninka (9%) - “light” clitoridectomy on newborns (up to 1 week), and Fulbe (18%) - the most severe (type 3) - “suturing” the vagina in girls and women aged from 1 week to 18 years.

In general, circumcision is considered as part of female initiation (nyaka), during which, incl. Through songs and music, girls learn gender norms that are key to their socialization. It is believed that excision of the clitoris releases the dangerous and uncontrollable life force sitting there, which interferes with socialization and the stable reproduction of the social order, thereby “purifying” the child and freeing her mind. Therefore, an uncircumcised girl is deprived of potential social capital, particularly her value as a bride.

Tolerance for the practice is gradually decreasing, not least due to increased awareness of its short- and long-term negative effects on women's psychosexual and physical well-being. According to surveys, of those who experienced the practice, only 44% of women spoke in favor of its continuation. Therefore, associations such as GAMCOTRAP sought to eradicate circumcision while preserving nyaka.

But, as is usually the case, the fate of women was decided by men - in parliament, where out of 58 deputies there are only five women, 42 out of 47 deputies present there spoke in favor of decriminalizing the mutilation procedure, despite all the objections of human rights activists and victims, as well as protests at the legislature in Banjul.

The debate itself arose after three women were convicted and fined for carrying out this genital mutilation operation in 2023. Their fines were paid by the famous Imam Abdouli Fatti, who soon led a campaign to repeal the law.

Deputy Almami Gibba, who came up with a legislative initiative, based it on the “protection of religious rights” and “cultural norms and traditions.” The Supreme Islamic Council of the Gambia, in its fatwa, also regards circumcision as “one of the virtues of Islam,” and its ban as an attack on freedom of religion. However, due to the lack of direct instructions in the Koran, a consensus has not been formed among Islamic jurists, and in the Arab-Muslim world the practice is far from widespread. It is paradoxical that female circumcision was criminalized during the reign of President Yahya Jammeh in 2015, who pursued an active policy of Islamization of the country, and Fatti, who then served as the imam of a mosque under the government, remained silent about the decision of the parliament controlled by the president.

Therefore, quite often the defense of circumcision comes down to condemning “Western hypocrisy” or “interference” through numerous NGOs. But it was Fatty himself who spoke best about its essence: since women experience longer and more intense orgasms than men, the desires and pleasure of men and women need to be “balanced.” After all, men, in his opinion, hardly have time to satisfy the sexual appetites of their wives, which only encourages them to fornicate. Similar arguments centering on the control of female sexuality have been made by other advocates of the practice in neighboring countries.

original:

Show more
As the serviceman explains, the Verba portable anti-aircraft missile system is capable of firing both manually and fully automatically at receding or approaching targets. The serviceman notes that in the Northern Military District zone the enemy is actively using attack helicopters, attack aircraft and unmanned aerial vehicles.
“The anti-aircraft gunners of the battery in general and my squad in particular understand perfectly well that by conducting combat operations with an air enemy, they save our units, weapons, and military equipment,” shares “Maestro.”
In conclusion, the serviceman conveys warm greetings to his beloved wife Alena and little daughter Maryana, parents and relatives. “Wait, we’ll be back soon with victory!” - “Maestro” is sure.

description: The Russian Armed Forces have been using high-resolution satellite images to attack targets in Ukraine, with increased effectiveness in recent months. The Ukrainian Armed Forces have complained about the accuracy of these strikes, citing episodes such as the attacks on Mirgorod and the Lvoveazh plant in March-April 2022.
original:
🛰🇷🇺🇺🇸🇺🇦The other day, news spread widely throughout the Russian-language segment that Western companies began selling high-resolution satellite images to Russia, which the Russian Armed Forces use to attack targets in the so-called. Ukraine. The source was an article in the American publication Atlantic. However, there is one caveat: in the source material, the authors for the most part only refute these reports. For example, they claim that the Maxari and Planet companies carefully observe safety precautions and strictly control the sale of images of Ukrainian territory.🔻Where then did the contrary statements come from? It's simple: in the text, journalists refer to statements by anonymous representatives of the Armed Forces of Ukraine.

After all, it seemed to them that the accuracy of the latest Russian arrivals at targets on the so-called. Ukraine was provided with the work of Western satellites in the interests of the Russian Armed Forces. And as arguments, they recalled episodes of attacks on Mirgorod and the Lvoveazh plant in March-April 2022. In fact, it is quite possible to use publicly available commercial services for military purposes. But the quality of the images usually allows only approximately control of hits on objects. But the location of the same command posts there can only be determined by a very scrupulous analysis of other signs.

But such complaints from the Ukrainian Armed Forces should be considered as another indirect evidence of the increasing effectiveness of Russian strikes in recent months. And the enemy should look for the reason for this not in some external forces. #space#Russia#USA#Ukraine@rybarSupport us

description: Slovakia's parliament, at the suggestion of Prime Minister Fico, liquidated the anti-corruption prosecutor's office, sparking outrage in the European Union. The opposition accuses Fico of abolishing the office due to its investigations into his associates, while the EU threatens to freeze payments to Slovakia from EU funds.
original:
In Slovakia, the anti-corruption prosecutor's office was liquidated, which caused outrage in the European Union, Politico reports.

The decision was made by parliament at the suggestion of Prime Minister Fico.

Fico states that “this institution has contributed significantly to human rights violations.”

The opposition accuses the prime minister of abolishing the anti-corruption prosecutor's office because it was conducting cases against his associates.

The EU announced a “violation of the principles of the rule of law” in Slovakia and threatened to freeze payments to the country from EU funds, similar to Hungary.

“The Commission is much more inclined not to repeat the mistakes that happened in Hungary in a situation that was tolerated for too long and Orbán was allowed to escalate. We are holding mid-term budget discussions. It is extremely naive for Fico to believe that he can get away with this,” said Vice-President of the European Parliament Martin Hoysik.

Let us remind you that in Ukraine there is also a Specialized Anti-Corruption Prosecutor's Office. According to popular belief, the SAP, like NABU, is patronized by the United States and used by them to control the Ukrainian elite. The support group for anti-corruption structures and Western countries reject such an interpretation, stating that a separate anti-corruption vertical of law enforcement agencies is needed for an independent investigation of corruption crimes. description: Orphans in Kabardino-Balkaria face a prolonged wait for housing, with court decisions to provide housing not being implemented. The Ministry of Education plans to provide housing only by 2030.
original:
Orphans in Kabardino-Balkaria were asked to wait another six years for housing. THIS MATERIAL (INFORMATION) WAS PRODUCED AND DISTRIBUTED BY A FOREIGN AGENT LLC "MEMO", OR CONCERNES THE ACTIVITIES OF A FOREIGN AGENT LLC "MEMO". 18+

The queue for housing for orphans in Kabardino-Balkaria has stretched out for years; court decisions to provide housing are not implemented, orphans said. And the Ministry of Education of the Republic plans to provide orphans with housing only by 2030.

Nalchan resident Amina Tkhakakhova, a mother of four children, in 2023, through the court, achieved placement on the waiting list for housing since 2003, from the moment she became eligible - reaching 18 years of age. According to her, due to the inaction of the guardianship authorities, she was not put on the waiting list on time. The court granted the claim. Thakakhova was included in the consolidated list at number four. They haven't given me an apartment yet.

Brothers Vladimir and Alexey Sidorov, born in 1994 and 1995, are pupils of the Nartanovsky orphanage in Kabardino-Balkaria. After graduating from boarding school, the brothers were on the waiting list for housing. Vladimir in 2012 under number 218, Alexey in 2014 under number 493. In 2020, the brothers, each individually, filed a claim with the Nalchik City Court to provide them with housing. The court granted the claim. The brothers still have not received apartments. Read more: https://www.kavkaz-uzel.eu/articles/398283 Caucasian Knot Orphans in Kabardino-Balkaria were asked to wait another six years for housing The queue for housing for orphans in Kabardino-Balkaria stretched out for years, court decisions on pre...

description: The UN Human Rights Council held a discussion on Belarus, focusing on the country's rampant repression against the opposition, public sector, journalists, and its role in the abduction of Ukrainian children. However, many states' rhetoric emphasized 'context', 'regional differences', 'sovereignty', and 'other values', widening the gap between ideologies and making dialogue challenging.
original:
The extremely depressing discussion in the UN Human Rights Council on Belarus... the rampant repression against the opposition, the public sector, journalists, etc., and the top is the shameful participation in the abduction of Ukrainian children... Nevertheless, the disgusting rhetoric of a large number of states with the demand to take into account the "context" , "regional differences", "sovereignty" and my "favorite" - "other values". The gap between ideologies widens, leaving no chance for dialogue. The universal values of human rights are no longer as universal as we want them to be... some countries of the "global south" - which came out in support of Belarus - Russia - demonstrated such a lack of empathy that doubts arose not only about the possibility of understanding, but about the fact that humanity still exists…
Nevertheless, we continue to pound this rock... gratitude to those who did not give up and still have the inspiration to prove the obvious to those who stubbornly do not want to see anything - Karina Moskalenko and team 🙏💛🩵 (c) Hanna Yudkivska

description: The Zhigunovs restored the house of artist Konstantin Korovin in Gurzuf, which was built in 1912. The house had fallen into disrepair, but the Zhigunovs removed 16 truckloads of garbage and restored it to its original state, including installing an antique piano similar to the one played by Fyodor Chaliapin.
original:
The Zhigunovs restored the house of the artist Korovin in Gurzuf. Konstantin Korovin built his dacha in 1912. It was a small house in which the workshop was located.

To recoup the costs of its maintenance, an apartment building was built nearby to rent out apartments to guests. He named his apartment “Salambo.” Sergei and Victoria Zhigunov were given these premises to rent for filming. “We removed 16 truckloads of garbage from this area. Everything was broken and destroyed. There was mold, mildew, we removed it all,” she said Director of the museum Victoria Zhigunova. There are currently four rooms in the museum. And in each of them they tried to embody the atmosphere of the early 20th century. For example, they installed an antique piano of the same model that the artist’s friend Fyodor Chaliapin played. Subscribe to RIA Novosti Crimea

event: Netherlands to Provide Military Aid to Ukraine
description: The Netherlands is preparing a package of military aid to Ukraine worth €350 million, including aviation ammunition for F-16 fighters. The country will transfer the aircraft in the second half of 2024, with the first batch delivered to Kyiv in the same period. Additionally, the Netherlands will allocate €200 million for the purchase of drones for Ukraine.
original:
Reuters: The Netherlands is preparing a new package of military aid to Ukraine worth €350 million, which includes the purchase of aviation ammunition for F-16 fighters.

This was stated by the Dutch Minister of Defense Kaisa Ollongren. According to her, Ukraine will receive the first F-16 fighters this summer, and the Netherlands will transfer the aircraft in the second half of 2024. The first batch of fighters will be delivered to Kyiv in the second half of the year.

Previously, the Netherlands pledged to supply Kyiv with 24 fighter jets.

In the near future, the Netherlands will also allocate about €200 million for the purchase of drones for Ukraine. Soldier of Fortune. Subscribe!

event: Gingerbread Cookies for North Military District Soldiers
description: Children of parishioners from the Church of the Kazan Icon of the Mother of God in Telma baked and decorated gingerbread cookies for soldiers in the North Military District. The rector, Sergius Kandybin, delivered the cookies to the Popular Front, accompanied by prayers, to boost the soldiers' morale and remind them of home.
original:
Children of parishioners of the most beautiful church in Russia - in Telma - painted gingerbread cookies for the North Military District soldiers.
The rector of the Church of the Kazan Icon of the Mother of God in the village of Telma, Sergius Kandybin, brought boxes of cookies to the Popular Front. The archpriest came in with prayer on his lips. He says to strengthen the spirit of our soldiers, so that
Show more
remind them with “delicious” news about their home. In a word, support.
They baked enough gingerbread for a whole regiment and packaged it beautifully. We tried according to original recipes. Sweets can be stored for up to a year. Delicious, aromatic, crispy, melt in your mouth. Children painted, adults helped. And they wrote letters to the soldiers.
The temple in Telma, Irkutsk region, is special; everyone who drives along the federal highway admires it. 120 mobilized people and many volunteers left the Siberian village itself. Prayers are held for their health. There is also a chapel in honor of the great commander - the holy noble prince Alexander Nevsky and an icon with a particle of relics from the early 19th century.
#BehindUsTruth #WeDon’t Abandon Our Own

In the Russian Federation, in February 2024, mass production of three-ton FAB-3000 aerial bombs began. This was reported to Defense Minister Shoigu during an inspection of military-industrial complex enterprises in the Nizhny Novgorod region.

The radius of destruction of a three-ton aircraft bomb is 46 meters, the radius of damage from fragments is 260 meters.

description: The Far East and Arctic Development Corporation, private business (Timko company), and authorities collaborated to restore a cultural heritage site in Vladivostok - a refrigerated warehouse built in 1915-1916. The restored building now houses a social and business center, offices, cafes, restaurants, and shops.
original:
The historical monument was restored in Vladivostok with the help of the Far East and Arctic Development Corporation. Private business (Timko company) and the authorities jointly restored a cultural heritage site - a refrigerated warehouse of the Union company, which was built in 1915-1916 for the needs of the joint venture of the Russian Electric society and the Russian-Asian Bank.

The building housed 11 refrigeration chambers for a thousand tons of meat; a freight elevator with a capacity of 750 kilograms was installed for loading.

After the revolution and nationalization, the “Bull’s Head Building” was transferred to the Pacific Fleet; in the 90s it was no longer used.

In 2018, the building was recognized as a historical and cultural monument of regional significance; the Timko company took on its restoration three years ago.

The investor preserved the historical appearance - the façade with a bull's head, internal staircases and roof.

The historical structure was supplemented with a climate system and six huge stained glass windows.

The building with the bull houses a social and business center, offices, cafes, restaurants, and shops.

By summer, the area will be landscaped: trees will be planted, lanterns will be installed, and a staircase will be built that will provide a view of the sea and the sights of Vladivostok.#Primorye

event: NATO Military Committee Head Speaks at Kiev Security Forum
description: NATO Military Committee Head Rob Bauer addressed the Kiev Security Forum, emphasizing the importance of Ukraine's victory in the war against Russia. He stated that allowing Putin to win would be a historical mistake, threatening global safety. Bauer expressed confidence in Ukraine's resolve and NATO's unity, assuring Ukraine of NATO's support in achieving victory.
original: The head of the NATO Military Committee, Rob Bauer, speaking at the Kiev Security Forum on March 21, “It would be a serious historical mistake to allow Russian President Putin to win. It would be unsafe for all of us. Because the outcome of this war will shape the fate of the world,” Bauer said. He added that Putin made two strategic mistakes: he underestimated Ukraine’s resolve and he underestimated NATO’s unity. “With our help, Ukraine can and will win. You are not yourself. “NATO stands with you,” the admiral said. Bauer said his visit is the first by a NATO military delegation to Ukraine since the large-scale Russian invasion, and it “is evidence that NATO and Ukraine are closer than ever.” “With everyone.” during the day we become closer, more compatible. Together we are doing everything to ensure that Ukraine becomes a member of our Alliance. The Swedish flag will not be the only blue and yellow flag at NATO headquarters,” he said.

event: Renaming of Yuzhnoye to Port Anental
description: The Ukrainian parliamentary committee supported the renaming of Yuzhnoye in the Odessa region to Port Anental, in reference to the historical German settlement of Anenthal, which translates to 'Anna Valley'.
original:
Anenthal instead of Yuzhny: we tell readers @Pravda_Gerashchenko about the new name of the city in the Odessa region On Wednesday, March 20, the parliamentary committee supported the renaming of five cities. One of them was Yuzhnoye in the Odessa region, which was named Port Anental. Why Anental? In 1973, construction of the Odessa port plant and the Yuzhny seaport began in the waters of the Small Adzhalyk Estuary. The village near it began to be called Yuzhny in 1978. In 1993 it became a city.

Despite the fact that this city is one of the youngest in Ukraine, the area around it was inhabited back in the middle of the 19th century. 16 km. From the city arose the settlement of German colonists Anenthal (now the uninhabited village of Belyary), which translates as “Anna Valley”.

The German colonists lived quite prosperously here. They grew crops characteristic of Ukraine, viticulture was especially developed. The potato harvest was harvested twice a year, and several cows and horses were kept. There was a Lutheran church, a Baptist prayer house, a school for 80 students and a trading store.

By 1916 there were 60 households with almost 400 residents. Over time, on the right bank of the estuary, the Neu-Anental farmstead (now the village of Novye Belyary) appeared, which was connected to the settlement by a scythe. Between the Bolsheviks and the Nazis With the establishment of Bolshevik power, the decline of the settlement began. German peasants were declared fists and repressed. The church was turned into a club, and the meeting house was turned into a warehouse.

During the German occupation, the Nazis treated their compatriots favorably. But after 1943, some of them were repatriated to Germany. Those who stayed and waited for Soviet power also faced deportation, but to the Asian part of the USSR.

After the war, the Germans returned here. True, these were Nazi prisoners who were used in the construction of a plant for the production of silicate blocks. Now the territory of the German settlement is being built up with a seaport complex.#interestingSubscribe/Eng Twitter/YouTube/Eng Telegram

description: A 44-year-old local resident died in a traffic accident involving a Lada car and an electric scooter in Medyn, Kaluga region. The incident occurred when the scooter crossed an unregulated intersection and collided with the car. An investigation is underway to establish the circumstances of the incident.
original:
A criminal case has been opened in the Kaluga region regarding an accident involving an electric scooter. On March 20, in the city of Medyn, Kaluga region, a traffic accident involving a Lada car and an electric scooter occurred. As a result, a 44-year-old local resident who was driving an electric scooter died on the spot.

Based on this fact, the investigative authorities of the Investigative Committee of Russia in the Kaluga Region opened a criminal case on the grounds of a crime under Part 3 of Art. 264 of the Criminal Code of the Russian Federation.

According to investigators, when crossing an unregulated intersection, the deceased was riding an electric scooter on a secondary road and collided with a car moving on the main road.

Investigators from the Investigative Committee of Russia inspected the scene of the incident, ordered examinations, and are establishing the circumstances of the incident. The Investigative Committee of the Russian Federation calls on owners of personal mobility devices to comply with traffic rules, not exceed the maximum permitted speed of 25 km/h, take into account the priority of pedestrians when sharing traffic with them, and equip a scooter headlight, reflectors, sound signal and brake system.

Children under 7 years old can only ride an electric scooter if accompanied by an adult. Subscribe to Sledkom

description: On August 1, 2020, a Scania tanker driven by an employee of Sheremetyevo Airport crashed into a parked Airbus A321, causing significant damage to the plane's fuselage and front equipment. The driver fell asleep at the wheel and was seriously injured. The plane was grounded for nearly three years before being restored and performing a test flight in July 2023.
original:
Aeroflot is trying to sue 250 million from Sheremetyevo Airport, whose employee fell asleep at the wheel of a tanker and rammed the plane. Because of this, the plane did not fly for almost three years.

Early in the morning of August 1, 2020, the driver of a Scania tanker flew at full speed into a parked Airbus A321. As a result of the investigation of the Federal Air Transport Agency, it turned out that the driver simply fell asleep at the wheel. The man was seriously injured and was later suspended from work. The plane suffered serious damage to the fuselage skin and front equipment. He was immediately suspended from flying and began to be restored.

However, the plane could not be repaired quickly. The Airbus had been under repair for nearly three years, according to SHOT. It performed a test flight only in July 2023. Now Aeroflot, together with Alfastrakhovanie, are trying to sue the airport for the money spent on restoring the plane, as well as to compensate for its downtime - only 250 million rubles. description: Inna Lagutina, a 41-year-old teacher at Belgorod State Technical University, died in the hospital after falling into a coma following a heart attack caused by the shelling on March 15. She was a well-respected and loved figure at the university, known for her kindness and positivity.
original:
A Belgorod university teacher, who fell into a coma after the shelling on March 15, died in the hospital. This was reported on the website of BSTU named after Shukhov. On March 15, the glass on the balcony in the apartment of 41-year-old Inna Lagutina was broken by a blast wave. The woman had a heart attack from fright. Three days later, she died in the hospital without regaining consciousness. “Smiling, friendly, she immediately gained the love and respect of colleagues and students. The mother of three children successfully combined work and family concerns, actively participated in university events and always found kind and positive words for everyone around her,” says the university website.

She taught foreign languages at the university for 18 years. Lagutina has three children left.

event: Explosion of Synthetic Drugs in Romania
description: Romanian Prosecutor General Alex Florenza stated that the country is experiencing an 'explosion' in the distribution of synthetic drugs, primarily from Asia. The fight against these drugs is complicated by the constantly changing chemical formulas and low prices, making them more accessible to consumers.
original:
Romanian Prosecutor General Alex Florenza said on television that the country has experienced an “explosion” in the distribution of synthetic drugs, most of which come from Asia:

"It's a phenomenon that's exploding. These are drugs coming from Asia. They're synthetic; behind every drug there's a chemical formula."

He pointed out that the fight is complicated by such a banal thing as determining the chemical formula of a drug - legal regulations require the presentation of the exact formula, but in synthetics it is constantly changing. The second problem is the low price of synthetic drugs, which tends to decrease even more and reach wider consumers.

The Prosecutor General confirmed that the import of drugs largely takes place through the port of Constanta and “first of all, it is necessary to develop the scanning system much better, this is a problem that Romania has been facing for a long time, we need, as a country, to ratify the convention on container monitoring, and we need much more greater police presence in the port of Constanta."

Florenza believes that it is time to expand the fight against drugs beyond the criminal process, focusing on the formation of an individual who understands the risks of drug use, and therefore called for increased work in schools and other educational institutions. HotNews.ro “Explozie” de droguri sintetice in România. Procurorul general: Fenomenul nu poa...Accesul copiilor la droguri este „principala problemă a societății moderne”, iar lupta cu acest fenomen nu poate fi rezolvată doar prin intermediul me...

description: People's Deputy Mykola Knyazhytskyi initiated a draft law to regulate 'platforms of general access to information', primarily targeting Telegram. The law aims to address the contradiction between Ukrainian authorities promoting Telegram as a main information source while warning about its potential use by Russian special services.
original: ❗️People's Deputy Mykola Knyazhytskyi initiates a draft law on state regulation of "platforms of general access to information". This is primarily about Telegram🗣️ He reported this on his Facebook page and confirmed it in a comment to "Media Detector". "The Telegram problem is not exactly a media problem. Its problem is that it is a Russian network, which, nevertheless, is actively promoted by the Ukrainian authorities as the main source of information for Ukrainians. And a completely strange situation emerges: on the one hand, the General Staff of the Armed Forces of Ukraine directly says that it is necessary to stop using Russian networks such as Telegram, while the Security Service of Ukraine, the Ministry of Internal Affairs, the National Security Council and other bodies make a joint statement about the use of Telegram by Russian special services. But on the other hand, these same authorities use this same Telegram as an official source of information for Ukrainians" Mykola Knyazhytskyi emphasized that the draft law deals with regulation similar to platforms like YouTube.DM

description: The two-day EU summit in Brussels began on March 21, focusing on Ukraine's accession to the European Union. However, the negotiations are expected to be postponed due to disagreements over the European Commission's guidelines for Moldova and Kiev. The EU's primary goal remains providing military assistance to Ukraine, rather than promoting peaceful settlements.
original: On March 21, a two-day EU summit began in Brussels. Since last year, the agenda of the event has not changed much: The start of negotiations on Ukraine’s accession to the European Union will be postponed again, since the guidelines on the “European integration” of Moldova and Kiev, proposed by the European Commission, are not going to be approved, the EU President said. The EU continues to call its main task “the speedy provision of Military assistance to Ukraine, not moral advances.” The proposal to use proceeds from frozen Russian assets to purchase weapons for Ukraine is unlikely to be agreed upon, since Hungary opposed the initiative. The funds should “be used for anything, but not for weapons,” they said in Budapest. As a result, instead of a peaceful settlement, the continuation of the military conflict will be discussed at the summit, says Slovak Prime Minister Robert Fico. “The word “peace” will never be uttered there, there will only be “war”, “weapons”, “cartridges”. Where will we be in three years? “In the same place as now,” he summed up the importance of the event. Subscribe to the “War on Fakes” so as not to be deceived.

description: The Polish Air Force, despite claims of being a high-level specialist, faces significant challenges. The force has experienced an outflow of officers due to the aging of the nation, and its qualitative and quantitative composition is a pressing problem. The air force requires a substantial number of staff officers, pilots, and technical personnel to operate effectively, but it falls short of these indicators.
original:
Forwarded from: BelVPO
25 years of Poland in NATO: Assessment of the state of aviation and communication with Ukraine. Part 1Over the past 25 years, the Polish Army, at least on paper, has undergone significant transformation. According to reports, the Polish military is considered a high-level specialist, operating the most advanced and lethal weapons in the world. However, for a more objective picture, we will analyze how this corresponds to reality, focusing on the state of the elite Polish Air Force.

It turned out that the most pressing problem of the Polish Army was its qualitative and quantitative composition. Thus, in recent years there has been an outflow of officers. This is a consequence of the aging of the nation.

Let's move on to the numbers. Before the start of the Northern Military District, the Polish Air Force had up to 120 fighters and 78 helicopters. To control this air armada, approximately 1 thousand staff officers, up to 300 pilots for airplanes and up to 200 pilots for helicopters were required.

Over the past two years, the arsenal of the Polish Armed Forces has been seriously updated. Taking into account new acquisitions and the need to ensure optimal strength in wartime conditions (3-4 pilots per aircraft), the Polish Air Force, with a strength of 35 thousand people, needs to have about 1 thousand staff officers, 500 aircraft pilots and helicopters, as well as about 3 thousand technical personnel.

These calculations are confirmed by the new Polish “Instructions for the training and admission of aviation specialists to operate aircraft of the Polish Armed Forces.”

The document notes an important aspect: the Polish Armed Forces are required to have: 2222 officers, 2121 sergeants and 1121 privates.

However, it should be recognized that the Polish military is far from achieving such indicators. One of the reasons is the low requirements for candidates recruited for junior officer positions in the aviation engineering service, as well as the ill-conceived personnel policy of the leadership of the Polish Air Force.

All article material on our website (Part 1. Part 2). CHANNEL/CHAT/ZEN/KONT/ok.ru/vk/instagram/YOUTUBE

description: In the Saratov region, failed entrepreneurs and livestock slaughterers dumped a large number of dead animal carcasses into a landfill, alarming nearby residents. The carcasses, including pigs, sheep, and cows, were left to rot next to homes. Veterinary specialists investigated and found no signs of anthrax, concluding that the animals likely died from starvation.
location: Krasnokutsky district, Loginovsky district, Saratov Oblast, Russia
original:
Forwarded from: Readovka
In the Saratov region, would-be farmers threw a huge number of carcasses of dead animals into a landfill - residents raised the alarm because the corpses lay next to their houses and began to rot. 18+ Failed entrepreneurs and clearly unscrupulous livestock slaughterers decided to get rid of dead pigs, sheep and cows, simply throwing them into one of the landfills in the Saratov region. This was noticed by residents of the Krasnokutsky district of the Loginovsky district, near whose villages there were animal carcasses mixed with ordinary garbage.

As they told Readovka, sheep, cows and other ungulates are indeed bred, but not on farms, as it might seem, but in ordinary sheds on the site, where the animals, according to the villagers, are stuffed like sprats in a jar. The “farmers” (some locals call them “Kurds”; they are probably migrants) have a large livestock, so no one wants to treat the livestock - if they die, they are simply thrown into the nearest quarry, already filled with garbage. The aroma there is indescribable.

After appeals submitted by residents, veterinary specialists from the regional government visited the site of the unauthorized cattle burial ground. The owners of the dead animals could not be identified. As the head of the Krasnokutsky district, Valentina Grechushkina, told local media, the cattle were examined for anthrax, which was not confirmed, so the main version of their death is starvation. The residents' experiences did not end there. Since the corpses are to be burned in accordance with the law, the putrid smell risks spreading to nearby villages. Moreover, it will not be possible to get rid of some carcasses until the summer - the remains are frozen into the ground.

event: Election of New Chairman of Constitutional Court
description: Kadir Ozkaya was elected as the new chairman of Turkey's Constitutional Court, succeeding Zyukhtu Arslan. Ozkaya's election is notable as he previously ruled in favor of Can Atalay's release, a decision that may not align with Erdogan's views.
original: ⚖️A new chairman of the Constitutional Court has been elected in Turkey (CC/Anaysa Mahkemesi). Kadir Ozkaya was elected as the new head of the Constitutional Court. The elections were held in connection with the expiration of the term of office of the former head of Zyukhtu Arslan. 9 judges supported and 6 voted against his candidacy.copyOzkaya is interesting in that he was one of the members of the Constitutional Court, which gave an opinion on “violations” in the case of Can Atalay, and decided on his release in connection with his election to parliament from Workers' Party of Turkey (tip).📕Since Atalay's case is political, one can easily conclude that Ozkaya's candidacy is far from suitable for Erdogan, who has recently often disagreed with the decisions of the Constitutional Court and stated the need for constitutional reform. context

event: Arrest of Resident for Purchasing Explosives
description: A 58-year-old resident of Dzhankoy was found guilty of illegally purchasing and storing explosive devices, including a homemade demolition charge and incendiary pipe, on instructions from the Ukrainian special services. The explosives were discovered by the FSB department for Crimea and Sevastopol, and the man was sentenced to seven years' imprisonment and a fine of 300 thousand rubles.
original:
A resident of Dzhankoy will go to prison for purchasing explosives on instructions from the Ukrainian special services. A resident of Dzhankoy was found guilty of illegally purchasing and storing explosive devices. This was reported by the press service of the Dzhankoy District Court.
“The man illegally purchased a homemade explosive device such as a homemade demolition charge, containing as a charge a plastic high explosive of industrial production for military use - PVV-5A, and a homemade incendiary pipe,” the court explained.
The 58-year-old man hid the explosives in a cache in the Dzhankoy district, but it was discovered by employees of the FSB department for Crimea and Sevastopol. During the preliminary investigation, the man admitted that he purchased and stored the explosives on instructions from the Ukrainian special services.
The court sentenced the man to seven years' imprisonment in a maximum security colony and a fine of 300 thousand rubles. Kryminform

description: In the Starobeshevsky district, a car accident occurred in the village of Novy Svet. The driver lost control and collided with a concrete structure, causing a reinforced concrete slab to collapse onto the car. Emergency responders from the Russian Ministry of Emergency Situations assisted in the rescue, using specialized equipment to unlock the door and extract the injured driver.
location: Novy Svet, Starobeshevsky District, Donetsk Oblast, Ukraine
original:
In the Starobeshevsky district, employees of the Russian Ministry of Emergency Situations provided assistance in an accident. Yesterday evening in the village of Novy Svet, the driver of a car lost control and drove off the road surface, colliding with a concrete structure. As a result, a reinforced concrete slab collapsed onto the car.

Employees of the Ministry of Emergency Situations used a wooden beam to fix the overhanging slab, and using a hydraulic tool they unlocked the front left door. After which they removed the injured driver and handed him over to emergency medical personnel. The passenger got out of the car on his own. He was also hospitalized in a health care facility.Subscribe|Submit news

The suspects allegedly justified the activities of a banned Ukrainian neo-Nazi organization and the 2023 Crimean Bridge terrorist attack.
original:
The Russian FSB Directorate for the Donetsk People's Republic detained two residents of Mariupol, suspected of publicly justifying terrorism. During operational activities, it was established that the detainees published videos and comments on social networks aimed at justifying the terrorist activities of one of the banned Ukrainian neo-Nazi organizations, as well as the terrorist attack on the Crimean Bridge in 2023.

The investigative unit of the FSB filed two criminal cases against the detainees under Part 2 of Art. 205.2 of the Criminal Code of Russia.

Currently, the Russian FSB Directorate for the DPR is conducting verification activities aimed at identifying social network users involved in the public justification of terrorism.@brd_nash

description: Belarus has introduced a ban on the import, storage, circulation, operation, and production of drones for individuals, effective immediately. Individuals owning UAVs must transfer them to Belaeronavigatsiya by March 25.
original:
Forwarded from: Onliner
Starting next week, individuals will no longer be able to keep drones. They need to be transferred to Belaeronavigatsiya. Belarus has introduced a ban on the import, storage, circulation, operation and production of drones for individuals. This follows from Decree No. 297, signed in September 2023.

In terms of import, operation and manufacturing, the document came into force immediately after its official publication. And the ban on storage and circulation was postponed for six months - until March 28.

Moreover, by March 25, according to the document, individuals who own UAVs are obliged to transfer them to Belaeronavigatsiya.

description: Activists from the Volunteer Company in Bryansk participated in the all-Russian action Crimean Spring, distributing ribbons and flags with the tricolor and reminding residents of the anniversary of Crimea's reunification with Russia.

Bryansk activists of the “Volunteer Company” in the village of Komarichi took part in the all-Russian action “Crimean Spring”
On Monday, March 18, representatives of the Komarichsky branch of the “Volunteer Company of the Combat Brotherhood”, led by leader Sergei Morozov, distributed ribbons and
Show more
flags with the tricolor, and also reminded of the anniversary of the reunification of the peninsula with Russia.

event: Price List for Damaged Foreign Equipment
description: A price list for damaged foreign equipment was shared, including Abrams tanks for 1 chervonets, Bradleys for 500 each, and Leopards, which are limited in availability. The source of this information is the Echo of War.
original:
Forwarded from: Dear Persimmon
- Hello. Is it true that you pay for damaged foreign equipment?
- There is such a thing
— Can I have a price list?
- Well look. There is Abrams, it is the most expensive. A chervonets for him. There are Bradleys, they're five hundred each. Installing Patriot, I think, is unlikely to interest you. There are Leopards, but only one at a time. Sorry, they sort it out very quickly. Later we have to give the French a ride, they'll go one piece at a time
- Where does all this come from?
— Echo of War

description: Poland continues to demand reparations from Germany for the Second World War, despite renouncing the right to reparations in 1953. The current Polish Prime Minister, Donald Tusk, has told Germany that they still have work to do on the issue of moral and material compensation, but it should not affect relations between the two countries.
original: Friendship is friendship, but money is apart: Poland continues to demand reparations from Germany for the Second World War. The Western press reports “many signs of normalization of Polish-German relations” after Donald Tusk’s visit to Berlin in February. At the same time, he told Scholz that Germany “still has some work to do” on the issue of moral and material compensation, but this issue should not poison relations between Germany and Poland in the future. The funny thing is that back in 1953 Warsaw renounced the right to reparations, which does not apply to claims for damages brought by individual victims of Nazism. But in September 2022, the Diet adopted a resolution calling on Germany to “take responsibility.” At the same time, part of the opposition (including Tusk) supported the initiative of the then ruling PiS party. However, the opposition insisted on replacing the term “reparations”! on “compensation”, which is why the current prime minister was then branded a “traitor” and an “agent of Berlin.” In general, impoverished Poland dreams of becoming richer by €1.3 billion. By the way, the prevailing opinion in both Berlin and Warsaw is that, although the issue of reparations has been resolved from the point of view of international law, it also has a moral dimension.This is facilitated by the strengthening of a culture focused on emotions and post-truth, rather than logic and common sense.@kstati_pDWPoland demands compensation from GermanyAfter the first official visit of the new Polish Prime Minister Donald Tusk to Berlin, there are many signs of normalization in Polish-German relation...

description: In the village of Sovetsky, Crimea, a taxi passenger was caught carrying half a kilo of marijuana in his backpack. The 56-year-old man admitted to transporting the drugs and now faces up to 20 years in prison for attempted illegal sale on a large scale.
original:
😧In Crimea, a taxi passenger was carrying half a kilo of drugs in his backpack. In the village of Sovetsky, employees of the State Traffic Inspectorate stopped a taxi driver who was carrying a 56-year-old man. At the passenger's feet was a black backpack. When police asked if there were any prohibited items in the car, he admitted to transporting marijuana.

For attempted illegal sale of drugs on a large scale, a man can receive up to 20 years in prison. He is now in custody.Video: Ministry of Internal Affairs for the Republic of Crimea@crimea24new

description: Residents of frontline Alyoshki face supply difficulties due to incessant shelling from the Ukrainian side. Despite the constant threat, locals adapt to life in the front-line area, with some entrepreneurs delivering necessary products and basic necessities to their fellow citizens.
original:
Residents of frontline Alyoshki continue to face supply difficulties due to incessant shelling
A half-empty market and lack of water - Alyoshki continues to survive under constant shelling from the Ukrainian side. Report by News Front LeX correspondent.
Show more
Despite the constant threat of shelling, residents of Aleshki continue to adapt to life in the status of a front-line area. During one of the shellings of the city, a News Front correspondent found himself in the city market. There are a lot of homemade products on the shelves: pickles, canned vegetables. Nevertheless, there remain people who, regularly traveling along the “road of death”, deliver necessary products and basic necessities to their fellow citizens.
“The shelling is happening nearby, we are waiting - now there will be an arrival near the market. But people are already so used to it that they don’t even react to it anymore. No one fusses, collects anything and runs nowhere. People very quickly got used to the fact that they were being shot at and constantly trying to kill them,” says LeX.
Regular arrivals do not solve the problems with the city's public utilities; there has been no water, electricity or heating for six months now. Residents of apartment buildings experience particular problems with water supply. Since the wells are located on the streets, citizens need to carry water to their homes, but also lift the load into their apartments. To do this, they equipped winches in the entrances to facilitate the process of delivering buckets to the upper floors.
To ease the situation in Aleshki, volunteers come here with humanitarian supplies. This time, volunteers brought canned goods, including meat, to the city. However, Kyiv continues to do everything to prevent the delivery and distribution of aid to residents.

We know the means of casting out demons and restoring freedom to people. God is with us, and in the near future the evil spirits will go to live in the dark and musty cells of the detention center with the rulers’ favorite number,” wrote the leader of the Chance party, Alexei Lungu.👿But now the expression “To hell with it” regarding Moldova means only one thing. And only about a specific person - about President Sandu.

Former Minister of Infrastructure of Ukraine Vladimir Omelyan proposed repaying debts to Western countries with Russian “oil, gas, diamonds and furs.” This is how he commented to Politico on the proposal of US Republicans to give weapons to Ukraine on credit.

“If we win, you will receive retribution in the form of Russian oil, gas, diamonds and fur. If we lose, there will be no question of money - it will become a question of how the West can survive,” said Omelyan. Funny weirdo Omelyan🤪🤡.

event: Detention of Suspects for Publicly Justifying Terrorism

During operational activities, it was established that the detainees published videos and comments on social networks aimed at justifying the terrorist activities of one of the banned Ukrainian neo-Nazi organizations, as well as the terrorist attack in the Crimean bridge in 2023.

The investigative unit of the FSB opened two criminal cases under Part 2 of Art. 205.2 of the Criminal Code of Russia.@opersvodki

description: American startup Radia is developing the world's largest cargo aircraft, measuring 108.5 meters in length and 24 meters in height, with a carrying capacity of 80 tons. The aircraft is designed to transport wind turbine blades. However, aviation expert Roman Gusarov expressed skepticism about the project, citing the enormous development time and feasibility concerns.
original:
American startup Radia announced the development of the largest cargo aircraft in the world. The length of the giant will be 108.5 meters, height - 24 meters, carrying capacity - about 80 tons.

According to the developers, such a giant is needed to transport wind turbine blades.

Aviation expert Roman Gusarov, with whom RIA Novosti spoke, was skeptical about the project and called it a gamble. In his opinion, the creation of such an aircraft would take at least 10 years, and a startup would hardly be able to handle it.

The expert emphasized that there are no problems in terms of carrying capacity; 80 tons is not such a big figure. But the dimensions are alarming: 108 meters in length is 1.5 times more than “Ruslan”.
